name: Marginal PDF
description:
Given a multivariable PDF \(f(x_1, x_2, ..., x_n)\) of a random vector \(X=(x^{(1)}=x_1, \:\:\ldots, x^{(d)}=x_n)\), we can find the marginal probability of a subset of random vectors in the event space \(\Omega\). That is to say, we can find \(\mathbb{P}(X=(\:\:\ldots, x^{(i-1)}=x_{i-1}, x^{(i+1)}=x_{i+1}, \:\:\ldots)) \:\: orall i\in[d]\) through:

$$f_{-i}(\:\:\ldots, x_{i-1}, x_{i+1}, \:\:\ldots)=\int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x_1, \:\:\ldots, x_d)dx_i$$

This action is "marginalizing" our PDF \(f\) such that it no longer depends on a certain \(x_i\); that is, any \(x_i\) is valid for our PDF and so \(f\) refers to the probability of a subset of events instead of a single event in \(\Omega\). We also note that:

$$p_X(x)=\int_y p_{X|Y}(x|y)p_Y(y)dy = \mathbb{E}[p_{X|Y}(X|Y)]$$
